content:
Just got this in Shortest mode, and wow... it's really not easy.

I was the only one to get 100%, including two bots who failed. I only managed to solve it quite late (took most of 15 minutes, including golfing it down).

I ended up using RegEx on the columns to great effect, but I hate to think of how I would have solved it otherwise... it's really tough, especially that 'Crazy cyclists!' test case!

I found this piece of RegEx very useful to define a block of either vehicle or 'nothing'.
/(11|101|10001|0+)/

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The contribution is quite distinct from most of the problems already in CoC, and it also relates to real life. The problem is not too complex, but the player will still be able to think about it enough for it to serve the purpose. It should be solvable in less than 5 minutes for most players, as the solution is quite simple. Overall, I think this is a great problem to be implemented into Clash of Code.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think this puzzle is a good mix of not being so easy that it will be finished in seconds, but also being simple enough that 5 minutes is a reasonable expectation, and 15 minutes is very likely.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle, clear statement, and original. While not "solvable in less than 5 minutes" like CodinGame wants, I would be happy to see this puzzle in CoC and I think the hints are very helpful for people scared of edge cases like me, so have an approval! ðŸš²ðŸš—ðŸš²

I expected this one to be a bit too challenging for a clash (see also comment of @aflorido below). However, this contribution reaped some upvotes in the end, so I decided to set it to Ready. I did include **hints** at the bottom of the statement, which hopefully brings this clash into the 5-15 minute range for most players.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I love the puzzle, but very tight timer for me.

I'm not fast and took 25 minutes: 8 minutes of reading the problem and tests and thinking on a solution, and 17 minutes implementing it.

Cases
* Suggest to change "cycles" to "bicycles" in the titles "Cars and cycles" (Test 5) and "Car or cycles?" (Test 7).

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.

Possibly too long for a clash - though it should be possible in 15 minutes and with quick sharp thinking within 5 minutes I think. But I look forward to your opinion :-).

And, I switched off Reverse, but on second thought it actually might be doable. Also here your opinion is welcome!
Wow only two comments from 5DN1L, that is a personal best I think. Thanks as usual!

Thanks for your honesty. While creating this puzzle I already suspected it might be better as an Easy In/Out Puzzle, but for a Classic Puzzle I prefer to make it as complete as possible and implement a variety of edge cases. I was too lazy for that so I chose the Clash format for now.

In all honesty, I am not sure how much time it would take me if I would encounter this clash as player. Once I had the realization that it works to iteratively find the first 1, check whether that one belongs to a bus or car or bicycle, turn the corresponding size into zeros and do that all over again, it kind of felt to be possible within the time-range of 5-15 minutes. But coming to that realization itself can probably take (quite) some time, and possibly some players accidentally fall into much more complex and time-intensive approaches.

Except if I soon get some very positive remarks, I will not keep it in this format. Maybe I will downsize it to only cars and bicycles (what do you think, would that bring it properly within Clash size?), and/or take my time to make a Classic Puzzle after all. Maybe one with also a bus/car accident
1001
0110
0000
0110
1001
or a tricycle
010
101
.

Oops ðŸ˜¬ sorry. There has been some doubt on the difficulty (see below comments).

I'm a fan of numpy arrays; in a 2d array I iteratively find the first leftmost tire, check from there whether there is tire below (cycle), or to the right (car) and otherwise it must be bus, and then turn the corresponding area into zeros and go to the next iteration. Personally I think that's much easier than regex (but I'm bad at regex anyway), and this approach is rather easy to implement in five minutes. However, the problem might be in coming up with this approach in time - or maybe I think too easy of my approach.

Yeah, the numpy part makes it seem a bit easier but I guess the approach is solvable with 2 nested x,y loops and doing the same thing with turning any found vehicles into 0's to avoid double-counting.
I was initially going to try something similar but a bit more naive in terms of just checking as many rows as needed before all the vehicles in those rows are the same, counting them and then discarding those rows, but then I looked at the crazy cyclists approach and realised there were row-overlaps, so this would fail.

Regex was just easier for me, because I tend to end up debugging a lot when I have too many conditions within nested loops, as I always end up making some little mistake that takes ages to isolate. :P It was a bit hacky, but it turned out to be quite accurate for your test cases.

(I sent you a forum DM with my golfed Ruby code, 186 chars)

Ok it got some upvotes in the end, so I decided to see how people react to it when it is in 'Ready'. I did include <<hints>> at the bottom of the statement, with the intention to help players directly in the right direction so that they can spend their time on coding the solution.

I started on a 'smart vehicle counter' in/out puzzle contribution, but was too lazy to continue with it for now. In that contribution, if it ever sees the light of day, I am planning to include about 5 vehicle types, as well as sometimes a pattern that is not matching any of those 5, so that your smart vehicle counter must recognize it as a sixth/seventh/... 'unknown vehicle' type and include that in the counting.

You're wrong! Your other contribution receives no comments from me ðŸ˜‚

You haven't changed the title for "Cars and cycles" (Test 5) ðŸ˜‰
Ah I assumed no comments implied you did not check it (yet). I can start including 'zero comments from 5DN1L' in my CV from now onðŸ¥³.
